properties.name: Coronado Cave
properties.notes:
Coronado Cave https://www.nps.gov/places/coronado-cave-place.htm

Pets are not allowed in the cave or on the Cave Trail.

Coronado cave is one of the few open, undeveloped caves in southern Arizona. The cave is a large cavern 600 feet long and in most places about 70 feet wide.The cave is located ~ .25 mile west of the visitor center on the north side of the road is the parking area for the trail. It is .5 mile to the cave entrance with an elevation gain of 500 feet. Some light scrambling over slick rocks is required to descend to the cave floor.

Be Prepared
Here is a list of important items to bring with you on your caving adventure:

  • At least TWO sources of light - it is absolutely pitch black dark in the back of the cave and it would be difficult to find your way out without a light (a smartphone flashlight does not count as a source of light).
  • Extra batteries
  • Gloves (touching cave walls and formations without gloves damages the cave and prohibits the growth of new formations)
  • The 10 essentials! (many search and rescue incidents begin with the phrase "it's only a short hike").
    • Water, sturdy shoes/boots, sun protection, map/compass, food/snacks, extra clothes and rain gear, saftey items (whistle), first aid kit, knife, backpack.
  • Although no park regulation requires a helmet, it is recommended in any caving excursion and is good practice.
Cave Safety
  • Never explore caves alone
  • Caving can be difficult and technical -- know your limitations and do not take risks beyond your endurance or comfort level
  • Always tell someone where you are going and when you'll be back (if you forgot, stop in the visitor center and tell a ranger!)
  • Have an emergency plan
  • Pay close attention to footing, in steep or technical situations maintain three points of contact (two feet, one hand; one foot, two hands)
  • If your light fails - stay put!
Cave Regulations
In order to preserve and protect the cave for now and future generations please observe the following rules:
  • Cave is closed between sunset and sunrise each day
  • Do not touch cave formations and avoid touching the cave walls - oils from skin can prevent the growth of new formations
  • No smoking in the cave or around the cave entrance
  • No littering - Pack it in, pack it out
  • Refrain from eating inside the cave
  • Do not scratch, paint, or place any form of graffiti in, or around the cave - your names and comments are welcome in the register at the visitor center but not on cave walls
  • Do not strike or deface cave formations
  • Do not remove rock fragments, cave formations, or artifacts from the cave
  • Fires, candles, torches, fireworks, and other open flames are not permitted
  • Dogs are not allowed in the cave or on the cave trail
  • Possession of alcoholic beverages and/or containers is the cave or on the cave trail are prohibited
  • Please do not urinate in the cave - restrooms are located at Montezuma Pass, the visitor center, and the picnic area
  • No camping
  • Avoid talking loudly, yelling, or playing music in the cave as bats are sensitive to noise

properties.name: Coronado Cave Trail
properties.notes:
Coronado Cave Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/coronado-cave-trail.htm No Pets Allowed
Distance: 1 Mile Round-Trip
Difficulty: Moderate
Elevation Change: 500 feet

The cave parking lot and trailhead is 0.25 miles west of the visitor center. The cave entrance is a 0.5 mile hike from the trailhead. Entering the cave requires scrambling down a steep, rocky slope. The cave itself extends 600 feet in length and has 20 foot high ceilings. Two flashlights/headlamps per person is recommended. Please do not touch cave walls or cave formations. For additional information, visit the park webpage.

properties.name: Coronado Peak Trail
properties.notes:
Coronado Peak Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/coronado-peak-trail.htm No Pets Allowed
Distance: 0.8 Miles Round-Trip
Difficulty: Easy
Elevation Change: 300 feet

This interpretative trail climbs from the trailhead at Montezuma Pass to Coronado Peak. Sweeping views of Sonora, Mexico and the San Pedro River and San Rafael Valleys can be enjoyed while resting on the benches under a shade ramada.

properties.name: Coronado Picnic Area
properties.notes:
Coronado Picnic Area https://www.nps.gov/places/coronado-picnic-area.htm Located near the visitor center, the picnic area offers 25 sites nestled in the trees and four ramadas. 

To get there you can walk the short trail across from the visitor center or take the road just west of the visitor center parking lot. The picnic area is open for day use only, camping and overnight parking are not allowed. Mild temperatures and low humidity provide pleasant opportunities in all seasons. Reservations are not accepted; the picnic area generally does not fill to capacity. Fires are permitted only in grills provided, but may be prohibited during high fire danger. Visitors need to bring their own charcoal or wood, hunting, woodcutting, and gathering of minerals and vegetation are prohibited. Pets should never be left unattended in vehicles and must be kept on a leash. Two ramadas with accessible sidewalks and picnic tables are available at the end of the picnic road. One accessible stall is available in each restroom. Restrooms are available 8am to 4pm.

A Special Use Permit is required for activities in the picnic area with more than 25 people.

properties.name: Coronado Picnic Area Restrooms
properties.notes:
Coronado Picnic Area Restrooms
https://www.nps.gov/places/coronado-picnic-area-restrooms.htm

The restroom facility at the Coronado Picnic Area is located along the road to the main picnic area. The restrooms have flush toilets, sinks with running water, and a water fountain. This restroom facility is open all year. One accessible stall is available in each restroom.

properties.name: Coronado Picnic Trail
properties.notes:
Coronado Picnic Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/picnic-trail.htm Pets Allowed on Leash
This short trail (.1 mile) will take you from the visitor center to the picnic area. The trails' grade does not meet accessability standards, but it is paved and the bridge is made of wood planks.

Along the trail you will see native plants and trees and a foot bridge takes you over the Montezuma Canyon Wash. It is also a good location for watching birds.

properties.name: Crest Trail
properties.notes:
Crest Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/crest-trail.htm Pets Allowed on Leash
Distance: 4 Miles Round-Trip Inside Park (10.6 Miles to Miller Peak)
Difficulty: Difficult
Elevation Change: 4000 feet to Miller Peak

The trailhead begins at the northeast end of Montezuma Pass parking area and climbs for 2 miles to the northwestern park boundary where it enters the Miller Peak Wilderness Area. It continues along the crest of the Huachuca Mountains to the turnoff for Miller Peak, the highest peak in the range. The Crest Trail is also part of the Arizona National Scenic Trail, an 800+ mile trail that extends from Mexico to Utah.

properties.name: Joe's Canyon Trail
properties.notes:
Joe's Canyon Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/joe-s-canyon-trail.htm No Pets Allowed
Distance: 6.2 Miles Round-Trip
Difficulty: Moderate/Difficult
Elevation Change: 1300 feet

This Trail can be accessed by one of two trailheads. One is across the road at the west end of the visitor center parking area. The other is at Montezuma Pass via the Coronado Peak Trail. When starting near the visitor center the trail climbs 1000 feet in the first mile with scenic views of Montezuma Canyon and San Pedro River Valley. As you continue along the saddle of Smuggler's Ridge, views into the grasslands of Sonora, Mexico will stretch out before you.

properties.name: Windmill Trail
properties.notes:
Windmill Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/windmill-trail.htm No Pets Allowed
Distance: 2 miles Round-Trip
Difficulty: Easy/Moderate
Elevation: 200 feet

The trailhead is located about 1 mile east of the visitor center. Park in the paved pull-out on the north side of the road near the fire danger indicator sign. Once a two-track road, the Windmill Trail provides access to the grasslands region of the park. The trail visits a historic windmill and corral before gently ascending into the foothills below Montezuma Peak. This trail also provides access to grassland habitat birding opportunities.

properties.name: Yaqui Ridge Trail
properties.notes:
Yaqui Ridge Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/yaqui-ridge-trail.htm No Pets Allowed
Distance: 2 Miles Round-Trip
Difficulty: Difficult
Elevation Change: 600 feet

This is a spur from Joe's Canyon Trail, the trail desends steeply to the US/Mexico border. Here you can view International Boundary Marker 102. This trail marks the southern terminus of the Arizona National Scenic Trail, an 800+ mile trail that extends from Mexico to Utah. It is against the law to cross over the fence into Mexico.
